editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE LOYAL LOVERS: A Tragi-Comedy. Written by Major COSMO MANUCHE.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Eglesfield at the Brazen Serpent in St Paul's Church-yard. 1652.

div.head: The Names of the Perſons preſented.

list.item: Corianus, A noble perſon betrothed to Apfia.
Sent-well, A creature of Gripe-man's, an Informer.
Perjurus, Servant, and Clark to Gripe-man.
Apfia, Servant to Leteſia, diſguiſed, and call'd Clarathea.

div.head: The Author to his Honorable Friends.
div.l: THink mee not proud as poor, when you ſhall ſee
I borrow not in my neceſsity.
And ſhould I ſteal, (though common in this age)
I ſhould (by ſome) be trap't in every page.
Then hue and cry comes forth, ſwiftly purſu'd
At length I'me taken, guiltie found, and mew'd.
Now, as for Juſtice, (faith) I'me like to finde
Her, like Fortune muſfled, if not ſtark blinde.
All Deprecations then, when deprehended,
Little availe mee; The Judge aſcended
Appears two Critick would bees, point blank ſwears
That all the wit they found about mee's theirs.
Which grant it were, let it be prais'd by ſence,
And 'twill be found not worth 'bove thirteen pence,
Which wants of halter proof. Now 'twere ill done
To hang a man ne're rob'd 'twixt ſun and ſun.
Nor have I ſtoln by night, (as I can think)
Unleſſe 'twere home to bed full fraight with drink.
But ſuch, as wanted virtue to infuſe
The Heliconian fire into my Muſe.
I know you'l gueſs what beer and ale can do,
Where daily care's had to procure that too.
My Jury now (might I but chooſe) ſhould be
Such as hath liv'd high, and know miſerie.
And if ſuch quit mee not, I'm ſure they'l ſay,
'Twas (partly) want of money ſpoyl'd my play.
Since Ile not ſteal, nor borrow, give mee wit;
'Tis in your power to make mee purchaſe it.
I cannot bluſh to own what comes from friends,
Give, and forgive, I have obtein'd my Ends.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Adraſtus, looking on his watch.

sp.speaker: Adraſtus.
sp.l: MY Youths have forfeited their pottle;
'Tis almoſt ten of clock.—

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.l: Come new new new new
Who buyes my new books here?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: What books have you got there, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.l: Newly come forth, and newly printed.
Why (Sir!) here is, how conſpicuouſly the Hogans are conculcated by their own Adulation.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Thoſe are hard words, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: But altogether in faſhion, I can aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Not with thoſe that underſtand them not.

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: Sir, you do moſt prodigiouſly miſtake; there being an order they ſhould paſſe without exception where there is the ſpirit of pronunciation.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Pray let me have more facetious language, and leſſe of your ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: Sir, I know your minde, And ſhall endeavour to pleaſure you preſently. Let mee ſee, here is A true, perfect, and exact account of Juſtice Dapper, and his Clark's Sodomitical revenue, to the great diſabling, and impoveriſhing the Active, and well-affected Females.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Come give mee that, what others have you?

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: Why here is another, of a famous Doctor's miraculous obteining the Philoſophers ſtone.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Doth your book ſpeak how?

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that either the Stone, or a perfect receit to obtein it, was preſerved in a wrack, and caſt on this ſhore; which hee hath purchaſed, to the unſpeakable content of all his beleevers.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: What is the price of them both?

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: A groat Sir, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Sirrah, that's too much, here's three pence for you.

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.p: Why Sir? Juſtice Dapper, and his Clerk's revenue is worth three pence; And do you think the Philoſophers Stone coſt mee nothing.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Here Crackrope, here's your money.
You make a brave trade of this, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.l: In troth Sir, but a bare livelyhood; (or where I get
A penny by the Philoſophers ſtone, there's Dapper and his Clark
Gets ten pounds by the well-affected female.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: 'Tis very probable; for they often for a touch
Change Droſſe into Gold. Farwell Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Book.
sp.l: Thank you good Maſter, I hope to have rare news for you next week.
Come new new. who buyes my choiſe new new here?
Pox on't. Here's a diſpenſation for oaths neceſſarie, ſticks damnably on my hands;
The people refuſing to buy, as if they had it all by Rote.—

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Adraſtus, good day to you: what, at your ſtudy thus early?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: A ſtudy your neglect invited mee to ſpend my idle time.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Tearm not that neglect (Dear friend) which wee'l confeſſe
A fault of Drowſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Come, come, you are ſluggards both. I hope you will confeſſe
You have forfeited your pottle.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: VVee have. And when you pleaſe demand it;
You'l finde us ready pay-maſters.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: But what books were you ſo ſeriouſly meditating on?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Strange books, which wee'l peruſe
VVhen you ſhall pay your forfeits.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: It wants not much of noon, what think you of it now?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: I, I, let's march.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: 'Tis ſure too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Not to be merry, wee have been ſad too long.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Then lead the way.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Come let us walk Symphronio, 'tis wee muſt pay:

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Sent-well, mee thinks thou art not half ſo active as thou wer't wont.
Sure thou art grown rich of late.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: 'Tis (as you ſay) of late, if I be rich.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: 'Tis thy own fault thou art not. Thou art young,
VVhen I was at thy years, I would have ſtirr'd my ſelf i-faith,
Such getting times as theſe.
VVhy there is old Firmstand would make half a dozen of us.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Yes, a weary with running up and down after him
As I have done. I have followed him, like his ſhadow,
Dayly this half year, and to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Sentwell, you give mee no account of the five pounds
You had of mee to furniſh your Comrades
That undertook to trap him.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Had it been more 't had gone; I am out of purſe an Angel
About that buſineſſe. You reckon ſtill what you are out of purſe,
But do forget what I have brought you in.
(I will not ſay by my juſt information)

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: I do remember, I do remember, Sent-well,
But could wee trap old Firmſtand,
VVee might lye ſtill and reſt a moneth.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Sir, I have tryed all wayes man could invent to undo him:
Intruded into his company, not only once or twice,
But times innumerable; And Proteus-like, varied my ſhape,
And fac't him down that I was not my ſelf.
Yet hee, ſo cautious (ſtill) in drink, or other waies,
That not a ſyllable, tending to th' States abuſe,
I e're could hear him utter.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: VVhy then wee muſt another way to work before hee leaves the town:
Hee never (yet) ſaw Perjurus my Clark.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: Never, to my beſt of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: It muſt be ſo, Sent-well: Perjurus and you ſhall to his
Lodging go; And under ſome pretence of buſineſſe
That Perjurus ſhall ſeem to have with him,
Fall in diſcourſe ot'h State.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: VVhich hee will hardly do, or if hee ſhould, hee'l cautious be
VVhat language hee delivers.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No matter, if that will not do, Perjurus and you ſhall ſwear.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: VVee heard him ſpeak treaſon 'gainſt the State.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Right, very right.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Not ſo very right neither. Sir, you know mee to be your creature,
But you have ſo ſlenderly rewarded mee for ſuch like actions,
I know not what to think on't.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: No more, no more, all ſhall be well. I muſt away to ſee
There's no injuſtice done about ſharing the VViddows goods
VVee caus'd to be plundered. Sent-well, let mee alone
'Bout eight of clock this evening to plot your buſineſſe
For old Firmſtand; and for thy part,
Thou ſhalt have trebble ſhare.—

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: I think ſo too. The trebble Gallowes, if wee had our due.—

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Miſtreſſe, have you any acquaintance in the Change?

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Not I, Clarathea: Haſt Thou?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Not I truely; but it matters not much, for I have often
Found ſtrangers to part with their Commodities
At cheaper rates then thoſe that would be thought our friends.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: You wagg, ſpeak ſoftly, or you'l be heard.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Now by the Gods I have not ſeen a rarer piece.
In all my travells.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Beſhrew mee but ſhee is handſom.
Let's walk and obſerve her.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Dear Symphronio, wait an opportunity to accoſt her maid, and know
Her name and being.—

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: So quick, ſhee's gone, I'le follow her, and it ſhall go hard but I'le be
Able to give you punctuall ſatisfaction.—
But do you hear, you'l not be ſcrupulous to pay
this debt, and pimp when fleſh invites.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: No, no, my friendſhip ſtand engaged.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: I'le take't, farewell.—

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: I feel an unaccuſtomed qualm, I hope I am not caught.
If I miſtake not, ſhe more then ordinarily eyed mee.
VVhy how now Adraſtus? have I ſtood the ſhock of ſo many ſparkling eyes, to ſhrink now in thy prime of judgment? but 'twill away again I hope.
Yet why may not ſhee deſerve my love? I have made no vow that I have broke, nor ere prophan'd at Cupid's Altar: Venus aſſiſt me then, and let it work.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Noble Adraſtus, what all alone? where's Symphronio?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Faith I have imployed him in a buſineſſe, hee'l not be ſcrupulous in telling thee.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: See here hee is come. Sure 'twas ſome merry buſineſſe hee looks ſo pleaſant 'bout the mouth. Symphronio prethee make us partakers of your mirth.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: That you ſhall, juſt at the turning out ot'h change
I gave the Maid a pull by the coat.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: VVhat Maid, in the name of Cupid?

sp.speaker: Symphr.
sp.l: Thou man of ignorance, be ſilent, and give ear.
Shee turn'd about, and with a ſmiling countenance
Told mee I was miſtaken, they were not for my turn.
Her Miſtreſſe hearing her, look't back, and bluſh't,
Then caus'd her man go forward.
I, reſolv'd not to return unſatisfied, fell on again,
And with a civil Confidence told her I had a reaſonable
Requeſt, ſhee, in two or three words could ſatisfie.
At which ſhe made a ſtand, and gave mee leave to ask her Miſtreſſe
Name, and dwelling. Shee readily anſwered,
'Twas more then ſhee had Commiſſion for to do.
Yet for that I look't like an honeſt Gentleman,
(That could not harbor a diſhonorable thought) ſhe would.—
Shee told mee her father, —And there ſhee ſtopt, and ſigth'd,
As if ſhe thought him unworthy ſo heavenly a childe.
At laſt ſhee brought it out, telling mee, her Maſter
(Father to that Gentlewoman) was call'd Gripe-man;
His dwelling in the High-ſtreet; And this his Daughter
And onely childe, was named Leteſia.
I courteouſly thank't her, and ſo departed.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Hey day, what ſtuffe's here? all this ceremony for a wench?
You might have courted (with leſſe ado) the holieſt
Siſter in the City, and have ſped too.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Peace, peace you wag; upon my ſoul ſhee is
A virtuous creature.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Prethe ingage not thy ſoul for the female ſex, they are brittle ware.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt adore her ſex during life,
Did'ſt thou but ſee her face.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Is it a friend of yours that hath the letting of her out,
You ſo extoll her?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Leave jeſting; By Jupiter I dare ſwear ſhee is virtuous;
Would I had never ſeen her face.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: By Cupid hee is ſerious; nay if the winde blow there,
Come, come, let's pack.
No cure for love like a good cup of ſack.—

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: How now Clarathea, what taken up i'th ſtreets by Gallants?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Not by Gallants, Miſtreſſe; And for taking up the place
Was not convenient; which had it been
I ſhould have ſaved him that labor,
And have taken up for him.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: You ſhould.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Faith like enough, had wee been both agreed.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Thou art a mad ſoul, but faith deal truly with mee,
What his buſineſſe was.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Cannot you gueſs?

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: 'Twere ſtrange I ſhould;
Do'ſt take mee for a Witch?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: No I'le beſworn, nor I beleeve hee neither; for if hee had,
Hee would not have ſo earneſtly enquired after you.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: After mee?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Even ſo; his buſineſſe was to know your name and habitation.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Prethee wench be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: By my maiden-head 'tis truth.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: That's but a tickliſh oath, may I beleeve it?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Seriouſly, moſt true.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: And didſt thou tell him?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: I did indeed.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Urg'd hee to know no more?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: But onely ſo. 'Tis your father calls, Away.—

div.stage: Enter Riggle, Sodome following her, and Mettle following him.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: That Lady ſhould be right by her ſwimming gate.
I am provok't, and muſt have eaſe. —calls.
Siſter, ſiſter, his't, his't, why ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Would you ought with mee, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Lady, 'tis dark.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: 'Tis very true. Sir! Can you make it lighter?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: You may with ſtanding on your head;
For there's no doubt you burn below. —aſide.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: My directions (Fair Lady!) will be
No ſtumbling block to you.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: No, I dare ſwear, ſhee will by them finde
A very even way to hell.
This is ſome zealous brother troubled with rebellious fleſh.
I will obſerve them further. —aſide.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: If my heartily profered ſervice appear not troubleſom,
I ſhall perform the duty of a ſervant,
And wait upon you home.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you. But mee thinks your habit
And your language are not well match't.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: However match't, they ſhall agree to do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: This is no Rogue. aſide.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Sir, to give you anſwer. I am this night to encounter
With a friend about ſome buſineſſe
That much concerns my livelyhood.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: I beleeve ſo; And may concern his death
If hee procure not the better Chirurgion. aſide.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Lady, ſhall I requeſt you make mee then ſo happy
As let mee know where I may wait on you to morrow?

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: So it be in the evening, where you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Pray name the place moſt convenient for you,
And I'le not faile to attend you.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: What think you of the Naked-boy in Fleſh lane?

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: The hour now, and I'le not fail you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: 'Tween four and fiveith' evening,

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Till when, your faithfull ſervant.
Lady, all happineſſe attend you.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: O here is rare ſport for Mounſieur Albinus,
My maſters friend.
Well, Brother Zealot, if my wits not fail,
I'le have an excellent Cure to cool your tail.

div.stage: Enter Adraſtus, Albinus, Symphronio, and Drawer, as in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Drawer, be ſure you let's have that that's right.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Sir, I'le play with any Vintner (confin'd within the circuit
Of a hundred mile) Canarie 'gainſt Canarie.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Well Sirrah, let your wine be rich as your words,
And I'le bet on your ſide.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Mettle, welcom to town.
How do our friends ith' countrey?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: All well, Sir. Sir, here are letters for you. gives Adraſtus letters.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Sirrah, I look't for you two dayes ago.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Sir, your letters ſpeak my occaſion of ſtay. Adraſt. reads to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: And how? And how honeſt Mettle?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Your faithfull ſervant, Sir.
I have rare ſport in chaſe for you.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: For mee, Mettle?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: For you Sir, if you pleaſe purſue it.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Here is a cup of Sack to your welcom to town, Mettle.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Nay give him t'other cup. What newes Adrastus?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: The newes is, they write to mee for newes.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Adraſtus, Lore your top ſail: Vive la Roy. —Albinus drinks.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Come, away with it; Symphronio, to you.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Thanks good Adraſtus.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Come Mettle, the rare ſport you talk off, what is't?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Why Sir? ſome hour ſince, making enquiry for my maſter,
(Though ſomewhat dark) I could diſcover a zealous Brother
In hot purſuit of a wench; hee followed her,
I followed him: at length with complementall language
Hee aſſaulted her, who ſeemed ſomewhat ſhy at firſt;
At laſt, pretending earneſt occaſions for her excuſe this night,
Shee engaged to morrow evening to meet him, 'twixt four and five.
The bargain driven thus, they parted ſeverall waies.
I followed the wench, and pretending my ſelf to be his man,
Told her, my maſter had conſidered, and would requeſt her
The meeting might be by three ith' afternoon.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: What deſign hadſt thou in that?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Sir, as thus: That if in caſe you and my maſter
Fancy a ſcene of mirth, l'le bring you to the place
By three oth' clock, where (without doubt)
You'l finde her. Then you have time enough before hee comes,
For to contrive (which without doubt ſhee will conſent to)
Some puniſhment fits your mirth, and worthy ſo baſe an abuſer
Of the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Excellent Mettle! Here drink this for mee. —gives him money.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: You binde mee to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Adrastus, Pox of your melancholy, there's no denyall,
You muſt (in this deſign) along with us to morrow.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: I ſhall conſider of it.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Conſider mee no conſiders, you muſt go with us.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Hee muſt, hee muſt.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Mettle, come hither. —Adraſt. & Mettle whiſper. Mett. goes of.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Prethee Adraſtus, ingeniouſly tell mee,
Doth not this wench, this ſhee fayrie-female trouble thee?
Thou wer't not wont to be thus off the hooks.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Wilt thou not laugh at mee, if I ſhould confeſſe?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Faith no: I ever could diſtinguiſh between a friend
Seriouſly deſerving pitie, and objects fit for laughter.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: I know not what you call being in love,
But if I not enjoy her, I muſt forget
There can be joy on earth.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Injoy? Do'ſt know what 'tis thou would'ſt injoy?
Shee may be (for ought I can perceive) thou know'ſt
Not worthy thy affection.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Can there be ſo much beauty
Without a world of virtue and deſert?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Symphromo, you know her fathers houſe.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: If what lier maid delivered to mee be true, I do.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Adraſtus, few hours will make known if ſhe worthlly deſerve,
Which when diſcovered, and that I finde her worthy thy affection,
Imploy Thy Albinus: And if I faile to ſerve Thee, to my laſt drop of blood,
May miſerie enforce mee take up arms againſt
My naturall Prince.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: The ſame wiſh I; And I know nothing worſe.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: My noble friends, I thank you, and cordially beleeve you,
What e're (through weakneſſe) I deſerve.
Now for contrivance, how to obtein that happy houre
Wherein I may reveal my thoughts to her, (none elſe being by)
To mee appeares miraculous.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: That, I'le engage my life, you ſpeedily ſhall do.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: It is impoſſible, how can'ſt thou contrive it?
It were a happineſſe I dare not hope for.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Be not too incredulous, this I'le perform,
Or ne're draw ſword again.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: My life for't, what hee undertakes, hee'l confidently
Go through with.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: O Symphronio, I know his will, would hee had power equall!

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: I hope on the condition I do your buſineſſe, you will
Accompany us to morrow to Mettle's Wench and holy Brother.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: I will, and what lies in mee to encreaſe your mirth
I really ſhall act.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Why that's well ſaid. Now for your buſineſſe.
Some time this night will I procure a ſuit of clothes, with which
(My periwick left off) I well may paſſe for round amongſt the Synod.
The iſſue of my buſineſſe expect to hear to morrow.
Drawer, Drawer, to pay?—

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall know preſently.—

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Name but your hour of return,
And wee'l expect you here.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: There's no place better; by nine or ten ith' morning
I will be with you.
Symphronio, give mee a note of the old mans houſe and name.—

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: That at our lodging you ſhall have.
Drawer, what's to pay?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Four ſhillings and a penny.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Eighteen pence club will do it.
Drawer, the reſt take for your pains.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Thank you Gentlemen, you are very kindly welcom.
Peerce, ſhow a light down ſtairs.
'Tis all paid ith'Kings-head,—
How have I loſt my liberty? Was ever Maid betrayed
By her eyes as I have been?
Dote on I know not what, or whom?
Muſt I languiſh for what I know's impoſſible to obtain?
Thy hopes, Leteſia, at beſt, are but that hee is noble, and a ſingle man.
Suppoſe this be, where ſhall I finde him, or of whom enquire
To eaſe my troubled ſoul?
I may aſwell ſearch for a Diamond in the main Ocean loſt,
And hope (alike) to finde it.
And yet, how much deſirous is my troubled heart
To entertain ſomething like hope?
Why ſhould his friend (for ſure hee muſt be ſo)
Enquire after mee? give my Maid money for diſcovering
My name and dwelling? All this is nothing,
And yet it may be ſomething: No it cannot neither;
For 'twas his friend enquired, and ſure his buſineſſe
Only concern'd himſelf.
Leteſia, Thy little hopes is daſh't. But if his friend
Come in his own behalf, I may enquire of him.
And that will breed a jealouſie, and may, ſuſpecting
Him his rivall, kill him, (which heaven forbid)
That muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: This is the third time
I have taken you alone in melancholy poſtures.
Venus grant you are not in love.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: In love, with what?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: That (if you pleaſe) lyes in your breaſt to reſolve mee.
There is one of the pitifull'ſt holy brethren within
To ſpeak with your father, that ever eyes beheld.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Know'ſt thou his buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Not I, but ſomething hee pretends to have with him
Of much concernment.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Know's my father of his being here?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: I'le then go call him.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: See, ſee, they are here.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Good morrow to you, fair Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: The like to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Leteſia leave us till I call you.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Now when you pleaſe, begin your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Sir, the common report of your juſt carriage in the holy cauſe
You undertake, hath encouraged mee to make my caſe known
To you, the well handling of which (I doubt not) but will
Be very advantagious to us both.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: You ſay wonderfull well, and to the purpoſe.
Pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: A repetition of ſuch truths as I could juſtly deliver
To your ample ſatisfaction, how laboriouſly active
I have been in the advancing this great cauſe,
Would be too tedious for you to undergo the hearing of;
Though my preſent condition muſt invite you to beleeve, —looks on himſelf.
I have been rather not rewarded at all, then meanly.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Sir, it is beleeved. Pray proceed to your preſent buſineſſe
Now in hand.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: I ſhall. And, to be ſhort, thus ſtands the caſe.
There is (and not far hence) a wanting Gentleman
Whoſe former rate of living being high, will eaſily be wrought
The only inſtrument to work our ends, his acquaintance
Being great with a young Gentleman hath long born
Armes againſt us; And one that onely truſts this
Gentleman with his abſconded living.
Now your promiſe that hee ſhall ſhare (of what your
Known Authoritie may eaſily wrack from him)
I'le ſtand engaged, makes him your creature.
A brace or two of thouſands will not be hurtfull,
And may be ſpared from twenty, which this my friend
Will make appear, not only that hee is worth,
But where it is.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Honeſtly ſpoken, very honeſtly ſpoken, and to he purpoſe,
Home to the purpoſe. And let mee tell you, you need
Not doubt, but that your care, and wiſely managing a buſineſſe
So much concernes the generall Good, ſhall largely be
Rewarded beyond your expectation;
Beleeve it honeſt Gentleman it ſhall.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Sir, I doubt it not. But for my friend, when hee hath
Diſcovered what wee can wiſh to know,
Wee'l hold him to't.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Right, right, our ſhares will mount the higher.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: The reſt I have to ſay, is, That I could wiſh,
And heartily, you would delay no time in being known
To this ſame Gentleman. Your ſummons ſhall procure
His preſence here, or where elſe you pleaſe, at two
Houres warning. Though (if my poor advice may ſtand)
I think your houſe the only place.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: By any means my houſe, Sir. And let mee intreat you
Make it yours, and your friends. Faith, what think you
Of a piece of Beef, and bring your friend?
Come, come, you ſhall dine with mee to day. Clarathea, Clarathea, —hee calls.
Fetch mee a pinte of ſack, and call Leteſia in.—
That baggage will have the green ſickneſſe,
Shee's ſpoil'd for want of exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Sir, will you have a whole pinte?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No words be gone, I ſay a whole pinte.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Miraculous! hee is not long lived ſure.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Well Sir, ſince you will have it ſo, I have conſidered,
Wee'l be your gueſt.—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: And welcom, heartily welcom honeſt Gentleman.
Leteſia, take ſpecial notice of this Gentleman and his friend, that when they come,
You bid them welcom, as my poor houſe can make them,
They will deſerve your acquaintance and reſpect.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Sir, your commands, and their deſert will merit much more
Then I can be ſerviceable in. But, to my power, I'le labour to deſerve
From both forgiveneſſe.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Such Angels of light, are onely capable of forgiving
What wee poor mortals treſpaſs.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No more, no more: Beſhrow mee Sir, this ſavours of the Court.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Pray Sir, let your charitie extend ſo far, to credit mee,
I hated much that Idol.—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Well ſaid wench, Fill, fill.
Sir, here's to you, and your noble friend.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Thank you, worthy Sir.
Health to you. Faireſt Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Lady, you cannot drink.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Shee is a very pingler, a very pingler.
Come Sir, t'other cup to you.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Thank you Generous Sir. —Drinks.
Verily it is more of the creature, then I have
So liberally taſted (in a fore-noon)
This ſanctified ten years.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Sir, time (at preſent) is pretious with mee, having a very
Great influence on the affairs of this Country,
And muſt take leave, but ſhall not fail you at the hour of twelve.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Till when, I humbly take my leave.
Fair Miſtris, your faithfull ſervant.—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Leteſia. I have invited this Gentleman and his friend
To dine with mee to day, let us have ſome things extraordinarie,
'Twill not be loſt: ſo good morrow, Girle.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: I do beleeve ſo: you ſeldom do invite thoſe you looſe by.
You Powers above! lay not your heavy judgments on a feeble
Maid for het fathers ſins; For I much ſear the crooked
Paths hee treads, portend our houſe no good.
Juſt Powers! protect the innocent.

div.stage: Enter Adraſtus, Symphronio, Mettle, Drawer, as in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What wine is it, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Your beſt Canarie.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le draw you a pinte of the beſt ith' town, Sir

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Adraſtus, what is't a clock by your watch?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: 'Tis ſomewhat more then nine. —looks in his watch.
Albinus promiſed to be here before noon.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: My life on't, that hee'l perform. And were you not
Acquainted with his change of habit, I am confident
You would not know him.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Is hee ſo metamorphoſed?

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: As e're man was: Hee looks ſo like a factious Brother,
That the Synod, though utterly againſt any enjoying
Pluralities but themſelves, could not leſſe beſtow upon him
Then three Benefices.

sp.speaker: Adrast.
sp.p: 'Twere rare ſport to be a ſpectator how hee behaves himſelf.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Wee ſhall have that at large when he returns.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, there is one below deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Why didſt not bid him come up?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Faith (Sir!) hee looks ſo like a factious Brother,
I thought you'd be offended.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Go, prethee bid him come up.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: 'Tis hee; wee muſt take no notice who hee is
Before the Drawer.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Save you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: You are welcom, Sir! I am glad to ſee you well.
Pray ſit down. Drawer, reach a chair.
And how doth our noble friend? Drawer is call'd without.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I come, I come; Anon, anon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: In perfect health; And how, and how, Gentlemen?
Faith, how do you like my ſhape?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: I hardly can beleeve that thou can'ſt be Albinus.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Very likely; nor that you are (this day) to dine with Leteſia
Your fair Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Yes; that I ſhall be to dine with her I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Thou man of little faith.
Mettle, fill mee a glaſſe of ſack.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Here (Sir!) here's wine.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Here Symphronio, here's to Hollands Maſter-piece.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: You are very merry Albinus.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: And ſo may you be if you pleaſe,
I am ſure you have cauſe enough.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Prethee Mad-cap be ſerious, Didſt thou ſee her?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Yes, by this fleſh and blood did I, and feel her too;
Had I not loved thee well, I had become my own petitioner
And deceived thy truſt.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Dear Albinus, be ſerious; And let mee know
The event of thy proceedings.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Mark then, and rejoice, for by our friendſhip
I'le utter nought but truth.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Then I beleeve thee; Prethee proceed.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Then thus: This morning early (as well Symphrenio
Can witneſſe) I parted with him. And as hee directed,
Towards Gripe-mans houſe I ſteered my courſe.
Where when arrived, and knocking at the door,
There comes a wench, demanding what my buſineſſe was.
I, in a zealous tone (as if I had worn my own clothes)
Told her, I deſired to ſpeak with her Maſter; (whoſe condition,
I had ever a pinte of wine with a poor botcher, his neer
Neighbour, ſufficiently enquired) ſhe intreated mee come in,
Telling mee, her Maſter (ſhee thought) was ready, but not
Come down. Away ſhee went, and no ſooner gone,
But down comes a bad father (for ſo I am given to underſtand)
To a moſt virtuous childe. I told him I had a buſineſſe
To impart that much concerned him. Hee immediately
Had mee into a handſom parlor, where I was bleſt
With a ſight of (I muſt confeſſe) your beauteous Miſtris;
(If e're my eyes beheld one) her father commanded his
Daughter and Maid-ſervant forth the room, which they
Obediently obeying, I began my ſtory, which as wee go
I'le tell you; for dine with him this day, I have engaged my ſelf you ſhall.
And this, dear friend, is truth.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: I know not how to husband this poor life I hold
To make thee ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Nay, if you complement, I'le diſ-engage my ſelf again.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt with thee I cannot.
Come, wee'l knock off, and all go to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Where you muſt ſmug your ſelf up for your encounter.
Mettle, wee muſt not forget three of clock this afternoon,
The whore muſt be remembred.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: And the rogue too, or I am much miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Adrast.
sp.p: Mettle, pay you the reckoning; Come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir. —

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Gripe-man, Adraſtus, Albinus, and Leteſia, as from dinner.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: SIr, wee thank you for your noble entertainment, and ſhall as men
You highly have obliged (to the uttermoſt of our poor power)
Faithfully ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you are heartily welcom to ſuch poor fare you have found.
And what was amiſſe to day, Leteſia,
Pray let it be your care next time to mend.
For (Gentlemen!) I ſhall expect you'l be my daily Gueſts.
Sir, pray a word with you. —

sp.speaker: Adrast.
sp.l: Sir, wee humbly thank you, and reſt your gratefull ſervants.
Lady, content; wait on your fair ſoul.
May I deſerve the honoured title of your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Sir, I want a judgment to pay deſert, yet never hated
Where I ne're found any.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Sir, be confident I ſhall not fail (ſpeedily)
To put it in execution.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Lady, the gratefull'ſt of your poor ſervants kiſſes your hand,
And humbly takes his leave.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Sir. —
'Tis hee: You juſt Powers! that have vouchſafe't
To hear the poor petitions of a diſtreſſed Virgin,
Be ſtill aſſiſting the humbleſt of your hand-maids.
What ſhould his buſineſſe with my father be?
There muſt be ſtrange pretences of large profit in it,
They hardly elſe ſhould be invited here.
My youth, and unexperience I have in Cupid's ſchool,
Puts me in doubt of what I fane would credit.
I do confeſſe (I bluſh to ſpeak the reſt) I eyed him more then
Became my modeſty to do; (I hope hee thought not ſo)
And if I not miſtake, his looks betrayed much more of love
Then buſineſſe with my father. Yes, yes, it muſt be ſo,
And yet it may be otherwaies. Suppoſe (which Venus grant hee may)
Hee love mee (if it be poſſible) as well as I love him,
The hopes I have to enjoy him with conſent of my father, is ſo little,
Deſpair awaits that thought.
His looks ſpeaks too much of honeſty to be rich enough, (as times go now)
For his conſent, No, no, Loteſia, it muſt be one dares lift his hand
Againſt his ſacred Prince, (which ſure hee dares not do)
And by ſiniſter waies hoard up unlawfull Wealth,
Muſt (by my fathers choice) be made my Bridegroom.
But I'le aſſoon imbrace a Leper,
As tye my ſelf to what my ſoul abhorres.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: What meditating, Miſtris, who your noble Gueſt ſhould be,
You din'd with all to day?

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: That requires but ſmall ſtudy;
They are men that come 'bout buſineſſe to my father.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: My maiden-head upon it, you will not finde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Why do'ſt thou laugh?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: To think how you miſtake.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Prethee, unfold thy riddles, and let mee know thy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Cannot you call to minde, you e're did ſee one
Or both of them before?

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Never to my beſt of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Why then I can aſſure you theſe are the very Gentlemen
Wee ſawith' Change the one of which enquired of mee
Your name and dwelling.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: That cannot be, they were all Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: If you examine ſtrictly, ſo you'l finde theſe to be.
For know, hee that wee took to be the pitifull holy brother,
Is, in diſguiſe, the Gentleman enquired of mee for you.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: It is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo; That I ſhould be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: What ſhould this mean, Clarathea? Canſt thou gueſſe?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Yes, that one (for both I cannot think)
Would fain make love to you.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: What e're it be (dear wench!) keep ſecret,
Till time reveal the event.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Be confident of mee; for when Clarathea ſhall betray
Your truſt, may ſhee live neglected,
And dye forgotten. —

div.stage: Enter Adraſt. Symphr. as in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Symphronio, Your haſte hath brought us hither an hour
Before our time, and 'tis too ſoon to drink
After ſo full a meal.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: 'Twas well conſidered; Let mee alone to drive away ſome
Time without the help of Sack.
Mettle hath perfectly got the part I gave him (if the
Bulls pizill put him not out)
And I have mine ex tempore.

sp.speaker: Adrast.
sp.p: Doth the Rogue know hee ſhall be baſted?

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Gently, hee doe's: But I am reſolved to try his utmoſt
Patience; ſee here, they are come. —

sp.speaker: Albinus,
sp.l: wee are reſolved
(Not knowing how wee may be encountred
When our expected company arrives) to paſs by drinking
For half an hour. Mettle, you are perfect in the part I gave you:

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Sir, I have not con'd this three dayes, yet
Dare prefume I am perfect.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Well, look to't, you know your forfeit, if you but miſs a word.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: If you are ready, come what will, I'le run the hazzard.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: But where are your properties?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: For thoſe, I ſhall furniſh my ſelf below. —

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Pox on't, I ſhall ne're hold out without ſome drink.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Sirrah, fetch us a quart of ſack. —

div.stage: Enter Mettle with a black gown, and pen, ink, paper, and books.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Here's Mettle. Prethee Albinus forbear your ſack,
They'l ſoon diſpatch the Scene.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Well ſirrah, let the ſack alone till wee call.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Come, come to your ſport, prepare, prepare.

div.stage: Aldraſt. Albin. ſeat themſelves. Mettle in an old black gown ſeats himſelf behinde a curtain, with ſome books, pen, ink, and paper before him, perſonating Phanaticus a Prieſt. Symphronio ſtanding behinde the hangings till his cue to Enter, perſonating Fly-blow a Butcher. Mettle drawes the curtain, and turnes over ſome accounts.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Let mee ſee, let mee it, gotten this week by incomes
From Miſtris Dunce a Common-Council mans wife, — Three pounds, a gold Ring two ſilver ſpoons worth thirty ſeven ſhillings.
From Miſtris Zeal widdow, — forty ſhillings.
From Miſtris Tartwit a Cooks wife, — three pounds.
From Miſtris Fat a Tanners wife, — fifty ſhillings.
From Miſtris Phime Feather-woman and widdow, — one pound ten.
From Miſtris Greaſe a Tallow-chandlers wife, — one pound two.
From Miſtris Error widdow, — forty ſhillings.
From Miſtris Extortion a Broakers wife, — Taſtetie to line a cloak.
From Goodwife Shuttle a gifted Weavers wife, — two fat Geeſe.
From Miſtris Fly-blow a Butchers wife— a filver bowle worth three pounds.
Why here is nineteen pound, nineteen ſhillings got with much eaſe.
How willing theſe poor ſoules, in body, and in purſe,
Are to contribute to the Elect!
For (to ſay truth) wee are choſen, but 'tis to cozen them.
I muſt abſcond: My ſpiritual exerciſe grows too laborious.
O for a Corniſh Curate from beyond ſea, to officiate in my
Abſence but for one moneth!
Would they forbear mee on the ſeventh day, I ſhould rub out
Much longer, and pleaſe much higher on the week dayes.
But to ſtand two hours ſpending (to no purpoſe) is too much.
sp.stage: Symphronio perſonating Fly-blow, knocks at Phanatious his door.
sp.l: Who's there? Upon my life another client.
A Greek or Hebrew book diſplayed doe's well. ſpreads open ſome books.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Here's one deſires admittance to you.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Who would you ſpeak withall?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: With your reverend ſelf, divine Sir.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: O hee is right, hoe is right. —opens the door, Fly blow enters.
Come in, Friend.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Save you, holy man.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: You alſo: What may your buſineſſe be?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A ſcruple Sir of conſcience, I fain would be deſolved in.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Reſolved, you would ſay, friend.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: 'Tis very right, reſolved I fain would be.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Time with the Elect is pretious, but to ſuch good works
As theſe wee are called; Friend, open your caſe.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Sir, I am poor but however have brought that with mee,
That ſhall ſhow I am willing (to my utmoſt ſtrength,
And abilitie) to give you ſatisfaction for your pains.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Honeſtly ſpoken, very honeſtly ſpoken,
And conſcientiouſly; pray begin.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Then thus I ſhall diſcover my ſecrets to you.
I finde my ſelf (of late) much given to rebellion,
Towards a poor woman, yet, young and luſtie.
A neighbours wiſe of mine, who (I fear) if I enjoy,
Will lye very heavy on mee.
Now, Sir, I have endeavoured to become a true
Subject to my ſelf, but finding my endeavours no way prevalent,
I ſhall deſire to be reſolved, how farre
Your diſpenſation (ſhee being none of the Elect)
Will extend towards the ſatisfying our venial deſires,

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: How far inclinable to your deſires finde you our Siſter?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Verily Sir, comfortably enclining.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Is her husband of able body for the procreation of the Elect?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: That caſe is doubtfull, and much to be fear'd,
Hee having known her this two year and upward
Without fruit thereof;
The woman having ever been laboriouſly endeavouring.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Brother, enough, enough, I ſay.
I have with attention heard you; and ſhall (as conſidering
It my own caſe) inſtruct you for your beſt advantage
Both of ſoul and body.
As for your rebellion, if your cauſe be wholeſomly
Advantagious to your profit, you may rebell,
As many others, and my ſelf (at preſent) do.
But ſo to rebell, as of neceſſitie muſt be prejudiciall to you
(Our ſiſter being impoveriſh't) I ſhall adviſe you to take
This comfortable admonition from mee, which is,
That you put on the Armour of Providence,
And cleave to a more beneficiall ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Divine Sir, I thank you; and do begin to finde your
Wholſom and comfortable admonition effectually to operate.
And that you may perceive, I came not altogether unfurniſh't
With what, I hope, ſhall (in ſome reaſonable meaſure)
Satisfie you. —Fly. layes off his cloak and diſcovers a Bulls pizil.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Good Sir, I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: You ſhall not need; Behold this ell of mettle, —advanoeth his pizil.
'Tis a good one: the Bull it once belong'd to
Coſt mee eight pounds.
Marry, I ſhall give nine for yours, if you waſte it not
Too much in the ſervice of the Elect.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Sir, what's your meaning?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: That you ſhall ſoon diſcover.
Now hear mee with attention:
Thou Metropolitan Imp of Satan, Monſter of mankinde,
Thou compound of Fornication and Adultery.
Nay, nay, ſtir not, nor let nothing of noiſe come from
Thy perjur'd tongue, which know can mollifie as much as tears can rocks.
Now, in a ſoftly tone, anſwer mee (if it be poſſible) nothing but truth
(A thing by thee rarely uttered) to what I ſhall demand.
You know one Fly-blow a Butchers wife.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Fly-blow, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Yes, Fly-blow Sir. Know, wretched miſcreant, ſhee hath diſcovered
Thy black ſoul to mee; and ſhould'ſt thou but utter one
Falſe ſyllable to thoſe known truths I ſhall ask from thee,
By all the Gods, I'le adde to my intended fury, and geld thee.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Forbid, you Powers, geld mee; I am undone then.
Sir, I ſhall confeſſe any I know, you pleaſe to ask mee.
Good Sir, be merciful. Geld mee.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: If truth ſo long forgotten by thee can be again remembred,
You may be mercifull to your ſelf, and ſave your Dowcets.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Thank you, good Sir; and be confident, what you ſhall
Pleaſe demand within the power of my utmoſt knowledg,
You fully ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Then to the purpoſe: How long have you been acquainted
With Miſtris Flye-blow?

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Verily, I ſhall moſt punctually reſolve you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Sirrah, anſwer me not in that ſniv'ling tone
You cheat the world with.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Why, Sir, it is ſome eight weeks and odd dayes
Since firſt I did enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Villain, did you enjoy her then?

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Pardon mee Sir, I mean no otherwaies then
The ſanctified company of a zealous ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Alter that tone (I ſay) or I ſhall whet —pulls out his knife, and offers to whet it at his ſteel hangs by his ſide.
You underſtand the reſt.
Sirrah, be ſhort; what money, and monies worth have you had
Of her? For Villain, know, that miſled
Woman is my wife. Phanaticus ſtarts.
What do you ſtart? (I muſt confeſſe, I bluſh to own her)
Come, be brief, and to a penny ſatisfie my demand,
Or you grow fat, and ſing well.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: I underſtand you, Sir, and ſhall caſt it up to a penny.
Let mee ſee, my book will tell mee; let mee ſee, —turns over his book of accounts.
The eleventh of Auguſt laſt, —twenty ſhillings.
Auguſt the eighteenth, —ten ſhillings.
The ſecond of September, —forty ſhillings.
The fourteenth of the ſame Moneth,— twenty ſhillings.
The firſt of October, —A ſilver bowle, to the value of three pounds.
This is to a penny, what ſhee hath been pleaſed to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And upon what tearmes did you receive it?

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Meerly her charitie, for good
And wholeſom admonition.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Indeed ſuch admonition requires conſideration,
Which you ſhall have. Come, come, depoſit
What with your Mountebanck tricks
You have juggled from her.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: No conſideration, Sir, for the paines
I have taken with your wife.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: For that, let me conſider—yes, I have thought
Of ſome valuable conſideration, worthy your care and paines,
But you muſt ſtand to my courteſie,
The bowle and money being tendered mee.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, moſt kindely.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nay, nay, for that, let it alone,
Till you ſee what I ſhall deſerve.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.p: Here is to a penny, Sir, what I have received of her. —Phanat. takes out of a desk the bowle and money.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Now, Sir, how ever you have plaid the knave
By deluding my wife, you ſhall be ſure
To finde mee a man of my word. —Fly-blow beats the Prieſt egregiouſly with a Bulls pizil.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: Hold Sir, if you be a man, conſider, and be mercifull;
Good Sir, conſider my Coat.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: 'Twas well remembred; I ſhall, I ſhall, and lay it on ſo much
The harder, you may feel the better through it.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: O Sir! draw in your pizil, (if you be a man) and ſpare mee
Till the next Lords day is paſt, or I ſhall be unable
To ſcatter the ſanctified ſeed of Reformation into the bowels
Of our dear Siſter-hood.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Their reverent hearing, and your inſtructions
Claimes good places in hell.
Sirrah, give thanks I am out of breath; Farwell.
Cheat mee once more, I'le ſend thee home to hell—.

sp.speaker: Phanat.
sp.l: I do beleeve you; A plague go with you, and your pizil.
The Rogue hath made jelly of mee.
Complain of this, I dare not for my credit, which, I muſt more
For my profit, then my conſcience value.
This muſt not unreveng'd go thus,
The ſlave is honeſt, that claws enough for mee
To ruine him, and his whole family. —Mettle pulls off his gown in great fury.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: How now, Mettle? This was but a rehearſal,
When is your reall day of performance.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Zwounds, I know not what jeſt there was on my ſide,
But I have all the reaſon in the world to beleeve
Hee was in earneſt.
You ſhall excuſe mee for acting the ſinner again in jeſt.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Indeed thy naturall doing of it is in earneſt,
Though wee applaud thy ſufferings in jeſt.
But how? but how, i-faith Mettle? was it not ſmartly perform'd?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Yes, on my ſide, I'le beſworn.
A plague on't, my gown had no lining in't neither,
Which you ne're conſidered.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Pox of a bad memory, I had ſpar'd thee elſe—.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: There is a Gentlewoman below enquires for you, Mettle.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Tell her I'le wait upon her ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Drawer, bring up ſome of your beſt ſack.
Another Scene as long as this had choak't mee.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir. —

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Mettle, take your Lady into the next room,
And as you finde her tractable to your defignes, acquaint us.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Shee muſt have my aſſiſtance to perſwade her to it.
Come Mettle let's to her.—

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Drawer, fill mee a brimmer.
Adraſtus, here's to the fair Leteſin, earths richeſt Jewell.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Too rich (I fear) for Mortals to enjoy.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Such another deſperate word, and, by all the Gods, I'le court
Her for my ſelf, and hope to enjoy her too. And, I think, I look
As like a Mortal (in this ſhape) as any brother in town.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Save you, Gallants. Pray bid this Lady welcom.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: I hope you ſpeak not in the plural number.
What think you, Lady, do I appear a Gallant? —ſhowes his cloaths.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Sir, though it be a thing much given to people of my profeſſion
To pry into the habit of a man, I look into the minde
And nobler part, and where I finde moſt worth,
I there moſt honour.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Spoke like the Queen of Amazons;
I muſt ſalute your judgment.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Sir, you miſtake, thoſe were my lips you kiſs't.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Lady, my ambition was to come as neer
Your judgment as I could.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Lady, your ſervant. —ſalutes her.
Nay, pray ſit down.

sp.speaker: Symphronio,
sp.l: 'twas well this
Gentlewoman had vertue enough to guard her,
I ſhould ſuſpect her being with you alone elſe.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Make you no body of Mettle? Or do you think,
Becauſe hee pleaſures you ſometimes,
Hee'l pimp for all your friends?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: What ſay you to this, Mettle?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I ſay, Sir, 'tis an office I never underſtood.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: That's very ſtrange, truly.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: To you, I do beleeve it is; I think I had beſt take up
The next room againſt our Brother comes;
Hee muſt not know ſhee is in our company.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: By no means. Carry a pinte of wine into it,
As if ſhee call'd for it.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretious youth.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Lady, Health to your deareſt ſervant. —Drinks

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Thank you, noble Sir. —

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I muſt have this pinte pot, hee is below already.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Miſtris, pray go into the next room,
And act your part toth' life.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Let mee alone; hee is not the firſt knave
That I have made a fool of.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Not by a brace of thouſands. Now will ſhee pick his pocket,
And hee lay fellony to our charge,
Then where lyes our ſcene of Mirth?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Faith, under the laſh. Symphronio, how do you
Like the Vermin you have had conference?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: They are together, the Rogue kiſs't,
You might have heard him hither.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Gentlemen! what's your plot? as yet
I am a ſtranger to your deſign.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Mettle, and I have ſtudied that.
What 'tis, the event ſhall ſhow. But now you talk of plots,
How goes your buſineſſe forward?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Adraſtus, art thou not a hungry?
Thou feed'ſt (to day) on nothing but thy Miſtris eyes,
And thoſe you fell upon without any grace.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: I do confeſſe
I hardly know what other food wee had; but as for grace,
The Gods ſend thee but half as much.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Symphronio, hee is now admitted.
Hee has got the Old mans good will.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: VVhat, to marry his Daughter?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Soft, and fair; there's ſomewhat more goes to getting his good will.
Hee hath free admittance to viſit his fair
Miſtris when hee pleaſes,
Marry, I beleeve, you might have had
Fathers, Mothers, and all the Kinns
Conſent beſides, (in a leſſe time) to have match't with your Lady
You parted with but now.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Thou look'ſt like one that would
Have married us, had wee been both agreed.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: The Rogue drinks like a fiſh, and ſhee plyes
Him with half pinte draughts; ſhee hath much ado
To keep his hands above board: the other cup will ripen him for your company,
Then 'tis my cue to Enter.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: VVill not the rogue be troubleſom?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Not long, if hee drink ſo faſt. And it
Shall be my care that hee ſhall want none here.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Mettle, how doth ſhee bear her drink?

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Hang her, ſhee'l bear any thing is laid upon her.
Now will I enter.

sp.speaker: Albin,
sp.l: And wee prepare to entertain the ſlave with gravitie.
Is all contrived, Symphronio? VVhat puniſhment wee
Lay upon the Rogue? for ſomething wee muſt do worth his
Remembrance.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: It is, it is; all is contrived.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: She hath prevail'd upon the Babe of Grace.
And hee prepared to enter.—

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Come near, come near, good Coſin.
Here's none but are my ſpecial friends,
I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Save you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: You are moſt nobly welcom. Mettle,
A chair there for the Gentleman. Miſtris, pray ſit here.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Thank you, good friend: why, I had thought I had loſt you all.
I think I have not ſeen you, nor your friends here, theſe eight or nine dayes.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: This whore is got half drunk, and ſhee will do it rarely. aſide.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Lady, 'tis true; but blame not us, but our occaſions, that enforc't us
To it: our buſineſſe now being over, wee'l be your daily viſitants.
Sir, a health to the greateſt honourer of this fair Ladies
Virtues. —drinks to Sodom.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Coſin, the Gentleman drinks to you.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Thank you, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Help the Gentleman to ſome wine.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Here Sir, pleaſe you drink. gives Sodom wine.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir; Lady, here's to you.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Sir, ſhee ſhould have it laſt.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Say you ſo? Then here's to you, Sir,
This fair Ladies ſervant.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir; Mettle, help the Gentleman. Sodom drinks and falls down, they help him up, and laugh.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Help, help, the Gentleman is troubled with the falling ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: How is it, Sir? chear up, all's well again.

sp.speaker: Rigg,
sp.l: How is it, Coſin? what, not well, ſweet heart?
Pray fetch him ſome ſtrong water.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: A pinte at leaſt. Courage, noble Sir; how is't?

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Very well. Sir,—but that I have got the hey-cot.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Your Coſin, Miſtris, is drunk.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: I hope not ſo.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Verily not drunk—I am—not drunk—I muſt
Confeſſe I—I—I have taſted liberally of the creature,
But you ſhall ſee—I am not drunk;
Here's to our Prince.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: How dares hee drink that health?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir.
Hee dares (now) drink his health, hee dares not name
But to revile, when hee's ſober.
That's bravely done. Sodom drinks.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: You'l pledge mee, Sir?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: That I will.
Here, Lady, here's to you.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Thanks, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: The beaſt ſleeps, the wine works rarely.
Shall I produce? The engine is in the next room.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Come, bring't in, bring't in,
'Twill cleanſe him better then a purge.
Sir, do you hear? do you hear? joggs Sod.
Come, come, hee is faſt.
Gentlemen, wee muſt have all your hands.

sp.speaker: Adrast.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Do you want my help?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: No, Miſtris, you have acted your part already.
Wee four make the compleat number.
Lady, pray ſhut the door.
Come, in with him, in with him, in with him. —they put him in a blanket and toſse him.
So, ſo, 'tis pretty well for the firſt heat.
Something hee would have ſaid, could hee have ſpoke;
Hee grumbled vilely.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Incomparable ſport! Fie, fie, you let him breathe
Too much. So, ſo, to work again. they toſs him as before.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Prethee, let him down, it has wrought;
The Rogue ſtinks like a pole-cat.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: How rank a Traytor ſmells.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Very true; eſpecially, in the noſtrils of the righteous.
The Rogue hath tir'd mee; hee looks white,
I fear wee have kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: No, no, hee breathes.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: How, do you like this ſport, Lady?

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: So well, I fain would have ſome more of it.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: The ſlave hath put my ſhoulders out of joint.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: What, ſhall wee leave him ſo?

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.p: Wee muſt per force, till wee have breath'd our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Hee that is weari'ſt I'le ſupply his place.
I fain would help to give him t'other ſtool.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Let him recover firſt, and then for t'other bout.

sp.speaker: Mettle,
sp.l: Fill me a glaſſe of ſack.

sp.speaker: Adrastus
sp.l: here's to the diſh you feaſted on to day.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Thanks, dear Friend, this Vlllain hath almoſt
Broke my winde. Lady to you. —drinks to Riggle.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.p: Your poor ſervant thanks you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Mettle, fill ſome wine; Come, now for t'other bout.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: A match, come Gentlemen, four corners and a fool.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: A knave, I am ſure; come, ho-vaſt. they toſs him as formerly.
So, ſo, ſo; 'tis well, 'tis very well; Gently, gently, down with him; hee grumbles.
Hee is not drunk, but hee hath taſted ſo liberally of the creature.
All this will not bring him to his ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Here's money fallen out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Adrast.
sp.l: Sirrah. diminiſh not a penny of his ill-got coin,
But put it in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Mettle, help mee to a Butchers prick or two.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.p: Here's a brace of great pins, if they will do.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.p: Yes, yes, they'l ſerve; give them them, —Symph. pins the blanket about Sodome.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: I'le ſwear you have performed it rarely.
What follows now? —

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Drawer, take you a care of this beaſt in mans cloaths,
Here let him lye (without diſturbance) till hee wakes.
Take charge of what hee hath,
That nothing be diminiſhed.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, be confident, none ſhall come neer him but my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Albin.
sp.l: Sirrah, make him pay the reckoning, and if hee enquire
(As queſtionleſſe hee will) tell him wee are all ſtrangers;
If hee refuſe to pay, wee will.
Here's for your paines.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, and carefully will perform your will.

sp.speaker: Mett.
sp.l: Good holy Brother, I muſt make bold to pin
This paper on your breaſt. —pins a paper on Sodome's breast.
Farwell, my fleſhly Saint.

sp.speaker: Symph.
sp.l: Wee are all indebted to this Lady for our Scene of mirth,
Without whoſe help wee had done nothing.
Lady, here's half a peece to keep you honeſt.

sp.speaker: Rigg.
sp.l: Thank you, courteous Sir, I ſhall endeavour to practiſe,
And what in my power lyes, I ſhall be glad to ſerve you in.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Lady.
Come, let's go, the ſport will be his wonder,
When hee wakes, which (by the Drawer)
Wee ſhall know at full. —

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sodome pin'd in a blanket.
div.l: VVHere have I been? Was ever man in ſuch a plight as I?
Sure I have been caſt into a ſleep, and hung in ſome painted
Cloth, to perſonate the prodigall.
What's here? a paper pin'd upon my breaſt?
Perhaps I am in Turkey, and this my price of ſale.
I muſt make bold to ſee how I am valued. —pulls the paper off from his breaſt, and reads.
Here lies a fleſhly ſaint did lately prank it,
Inſtead of ſheet, doe's pennance in a blanket.
This may be all true, And I beleeve the Author might have writ
To'ſt too. Yes, yes, it muſt be ſo, for I am pocky ſore.
They have given mee purging comfits too, for I'me
Damnable moiſt behinde; What company was I in?
I remember nothing but a whore, and that ſhee would
Needs carry mee to ſome friends of hers, and they have us'd mee thus.
No hat, nor cloake, —feels in his pocket, and pulls out his money.
'Tis ſtrange, they ſhould not be theeves,
And ſtranger that any other ſhould uſe mee thus.
Here's all my money to a penny.
I ſhall unfold this myſterie in time.
I hear by a-non, a-non, Sir, this is a tavern.
The door is lock't, and I muſt knock,
Though to my ſhame, I do't. hee knocks.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A-non, a-non, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Who ever us'd mee thus, ſure they dare not
Speak of it, for fear I come to know it, and puniſh them.
Drawer, how came I in this pickle?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Do you not know, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: Not I; prethee, honeſt Drawer, tell mee, and
I'le be thankfull to thee.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot tell, I do aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Who was in my company? Did you tend this rome?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I did, and if I not miſtake, there was three or four Gentlemen
And a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Know'ſt thou any of their names?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Not I, nor can remember I e're ſaw any of them before.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Where is my hat and cloak?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I have them ſafe below.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: That's ſome comfort yet; how long ſtayed the company here?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Four or five hours.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Is the reckoning paid?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Why did you let them go?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: What Authoritie had I to ſtay them?
They gave mee charge of your hat and cloak, and ſaid you loſt the reckoning,
Which you not being in a condition to deny,
They gave mee charge of you, and went their way.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: What is to pay?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A mark, within a penny.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: Fetch mee my hat and cloak, and here's your money.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: This Drawer is a rogue, and privy to my ſufferings,
But I muſt hold my tongue,

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, here is your cloak and hat.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.p: And here's your money.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you will remember the Drawer.

sp.speaker: Sod.
sp.l: I would I had as much reaſon to remember you
As you have mee,
I made you rare ſport, without all doubt.
Here take your blanket, are not the corners ſtretch't?
A very pretty wholeſom way of purge,
A plague of ſuch Phyſitians.
This is the fruits of wenching: ſhew mee the ſtairs;
I'le cautions be, how I come in ſuch ſnares. —
What ſhould this buſineſſe be, my father laid, ſo ſtrickt
A charge on mee to uſe them with reſpect?
'Tis out of ſome ſtrange hopes of profit they aſſure him.
How I ſhould learne it out? I know not.—

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Miſtris, the Gentleman that din'd here is at doore.
Enquiring for your father; ſhall I admit him in?

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Why, thou know'ſt my father is not within.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: All's one for that, I beleeve you can doe his buſineſſe better;
I'le call him in—

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: This wench, will ſhame mee.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Sir, my Maſter is not within.
Here's my young Miſtris, pleaſe you to impart
Your mind to her.
I thinke I have given him hint enough,
His lookes ſpeake him not faint hearted.
I'le leave you both to vent, or burſt. —aſide.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Fairſt Miſtris, I have ſomething of importance
To impart to your father.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Truely, Sir, hee is abroad, but if you pleaſe to expoſe ſome
Litle time to the hazzard of his comming home,
You are moſt kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Virtuous fair, One I thanke you. And ſince your
Noble ſoule hath deny'd to honour mee with this your
Courtous invitation, Pardon mee, ſweeteſt, if I endeavour
Not to let ſlip theſe happy minuts, the Gods (for ought I know)
Hath lent us to enjoy for our unmatchleſs happineſſe. —Shee ſtarts.
Nay ſtart not, ſweeteſt fair One, I have no frightful
Story to relate; I have forgot all things of horror
Since I became unable (more) to ſerve
My too much injur'd Prince.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: You have been then in theſe unhappy wars?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Pittie it had been, I ſhould have lived to ſee my Prince
Engaged, And I in debt to nature for my health
And limbs, and been a looker on.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: You ſpeak like one our Prince may juſtly call his
Loyall ſubject; it had been happy wee had all been ſuch.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Lady, ſo intirely I lov'd and honour'd you,
(E're you delivered this your Loyall ſoule.)
That were it (in nature poſſible) this might have added.
Know then, I have eſcap't theſe wars, to be (by your virtuous ſelfe)
Adjudg'd to live or dye.
Can you love? love mee ſo, to make mee yours.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a queſtion, requires much more deliberation, then
A ſuddaine anſwer. I muſt confeſs, it were a meanes
To quench thoſe flames (you do pretend to burn in) ſhould I,
And to a ſtranger to, ſo eaſie part, with what (ſo much)
Concerns my life and honour?

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: Miſtake mee not, ſweet ſaint, 'tis but a hope I beg,
Which a ſmall encouragement (from you) will make mee proud of.
Nor can I poſſibly urge, or dare expect that ſatisfaction from you,
That may impair your honour; let mee but hope,
And it ſhall be a happy prologue to my enſuing ſtory.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Sir, The hope you can expect from mee, and I in honour give,
Is this; I nothing ſee, but that your perſon, and your noble minde,
Deſerves a far more worthy wife then I can be.
But, Sir, I have a father, whoſe choice I muſt prefer (in duty)
If hee gives conſent, 'tis probable I may not repent it.

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.l: You have with joy unſpeakable tranſported mee
Above the clouds, there let mee drop, my fall might be the greater.
O! unſay that again; that very name of father hath chill'd my bloud,
And ſounds deſpair to my beguiling hopes.
Too well, I know what choice your father aims at;
Nor is fit you ſhould obey him, where the choice hee makes
Tends to your ruine.
Can the Woolf and Lamb imbrace? Or can there be
A ſympathy, where nature hath made antipathy?
Nor are you oblieged (by duty) to obey him in what's unjuſt.
You know his ſoul is black with ſin, Forgive mee, Deareſt,
That I am forc't to put you in minde, of what, I know,
You gladly would forget. Can you expect to enjoy one happy hour
With him, whoſe ſole delight muſt be to hoard up wealth,
Gotten by baſe ſiniſter meanes.
Beſides the daily curſes (for his ſake) you'l have.
Your door waſh't too, with tears of Orphans, and ſuch
Oppreſſed poor, as hee ſhall hourly boaſt hee hath undone.
For know, ſweet Creature, the free acceſſe wee at this preſent have,
To your fair ſelf, is onely that wee will aſſiſt him
In the ruine of a young Gentleman (for ought I know)
Unborn; but as wee do pretend, knowing his griping way of gain,
That I thereby might have the happy means
To make my love known to you.
I am a Gentleman, though (I muſt confeſſe) a husband
Far unworthy ſo Angelical a Beauty.
Nor have I to my wiſh (for your virtuous ſake) means
Worthy your acceptance. But what I have, (though not ſo poor to want)
Shall be enjoyed by mee, onely to do you ſervice.
And as you are known to be your fathers Heir,
You may ſuppoſe his wealth, more then your virtue, is what I aim at,
Make mee but happy in your ſelf,
Let him enjoy his pelf; which, when I covet,
May I live long forgotten of my friends, and looſe you love,
Which (with my life) muſt in one grave be buried.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Sir, what you have ſaid touching my fathers life,
I could with tears wiſh were not true.
And for your love to mee, I thank you, which
(To my poor power) I'le labor to requite.
Pray take this for preſent anſwer.
Indeed, I am not well, and muſt retire; onely
This, your language, I ſhall ſeriouſly weigh, and at our
Next meeting reſolve you more at large.
So heavens preſerve you. —

sp.speaker: Adraſt.
sp.p: Angels protect thee, ſweeteſt of thy Sex. —

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Wee have been at Old Firmſtand's Lodging, but to no purpoſe.
Hee left the town three dayes ſince, but will return for certain
Two dayes hence at furtheſt.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: It was ill luck you miſt him, but ſince his ſtay from town
Will be ſo ſhort, the matter is the leſſe.
Sent-well, here's money for your preſent wants,
You muſt about a buſineſſe preſently for mee,
You know the Golden-head.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: There lyes a Gentleman, his name Adraſtus,
I think you have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: Marry have I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: So much the better: Be ſure you dog him
Forth his Lodging, and if you houſe him in a tavern (as ten to one you will)
Uſe all the ſlights you can to Riggle into his company,
VVhich, if you cannot do, be ſure you take a rome, or wait ſo neer him,
You may diſcover what their diſcourſe is.
And let mee know what you can gather this night;
And if their plot (contrived) ſtand right, 'tis rare.
I'le firk my youngſters when they come to ſhare.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: Sir, I'le do my beſt, and doubt not to perform your will.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Go, go about it ſtraight, make haſte. —
Yes, yes, it muſt be ſo; Gripe. pulls out a letter. and reads it to himſelf.
There's danger in delayes: The Girle
Muſt from temptation, or ſhee's loſt.
Some few moneths more ſhee will be head-ſtrong,

And carve her own bits, which I'le in time prevent. — hee calls
Leteſia. Leteſia.
Leteſia, here's newes for you.
Your unkle Miſer, writes old Avaritia, likes well of
The match between his ſon and you.
And that becauſe hee would have you neer one another,
Hee thinks it fit you ſhould be at his houſe,
And ſojorn there a while, till things between us
Fully are agreed on.
You ſee, Girle, what a care I have of your well doing;
My thoughts are often hammering about your good,
When you full ſoundly ſleep; young Avaritia
Will make a wealthy husband for thee.
Up with your trinkets, and prepare to go:
Nay, no ſtudy, I have ſaid it, and it muſt be ſo. —

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Indeed it muſt not. Good Avaritia, match in your own
Dunghill, it will avoid a baſtard breed.
Money makes men ador'd, faith not by mee;
Virtue and honour crowns felicitie.
How now, Clarathea? Ar't ſure Sent-well is imployed
To pry into his actions?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Am I ſure I live? I ſtood by when your father gave the charge,
And the Villain undertook it greedily.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: How ſhall wee do to give Adraſtus notice of it?
This ſlave will diſcover elſe, they do delude my father,
And then wee are all undone.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: Why, faith, for once, (to do you ſervice) I'le to
His Lodging my ſelf. I heard what directions my Maſter
Gave him. Let mee alone to acquaint him with the plot;
But now I think on't too, I'le not go neither.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.p: Dear wench, why not?

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.p: Why Faith, cauſe you'l be jealous.

sp.speaker: Leteſ.
sp.l: Prethee, leave thy jeſting, by my life not I.
Tis more then time thou wer't gone.

sp.speaker: Clarath.
sp.l: You have prevailed; and I reſolved to venture. —
sp.stage: Enter Atheos, richly clad, admiring himſelf.
sp.l: Marry, Sir, this is ſomething like.
I ſee my Taylor can fit mee without taking meaſure of my conſcience.
The ſame quantitie ſerves, how large ſo ever,
Fools report 'tis ſtreach't.
What a handſom bug-bear it is, to 'fright men out of a happineſſe,
Their reaſon (wer't not enſlaved, by doting on a world ith' moon,
To recompence their pining Miſerie) muſt prompt them to enjoy. —puts off his hat.
Perſiſt in beggary, do, and let your admired conſcience
(Uſhered in with rags, and meagre chops)
Attend you to your graves; Where (if your duſt
More brighter ſhine then mine)
Be thankfull to the Glow-worm
Let mee imbrace this world, till I forbear
(For conſcience ſake) to enjoy, with full delights
What luſt unſatisfied deſires.
This dumb God I'le adore, Money, to thee
I'le ſacrifice, thou art my Deitie.
How now, Rogaſtos?
How drawes the lungs of our new Government,
The air of profit, (ſweeter then are the Arabian winds)
Into our garriſon?
Doth conſcience (ſtill) part freely with her outward
Garments, truſting the ſoul for to re-cloath the body?

sp.speaker: Rogast.
sp.l: As yet they gallop to their ſufferings, as wee can wiſh;
Only the Lady that wee raviſhed,
Hangs ſtill an arſe.

sp.speaker: Athe.
sp.l: Shee ſtill continues firm in belief,
It was the private Souldier.

sp.speaker: Rogaſt.
sp.l: Shee doe's; but wonders much there's no ſeverer ſearch
To apprehend what (fooliſhly) ſhee tearmes her foes.

sp.speaker: Athe.
sp.l: For that wee ſhall (with fair pretences) gild
Much thicker then her eyes can pierce.

sp.speaker: Rogaſt.
sp.l: As thus; the wrack ſhall force a guiltleſſe priſoner
To confeſſe the fact, which done before ſuch
Witneſſes as ſoon ſhall publiſh it,
Wee may (with ſafety) murder him,
And it cryed up for Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Athe.
sp.l: Securely contrived, (my better Genius) and politickly;
But wee'l forbear a while, to try what gentler
Means may work upon her (eaſily) beguil'd faith,
Which I ſhall make my ſtudy.
Rogaſtos▪ haſte, and give order the Foot
Be all drawn out.
That part oth' ſpoil wee ſeiz'd on laſt, I intend
For to diſtribute to all an equal ſhare,
As well to thoſe remained in garriſon,
As the party march't to take it.
It will unanimouſly beget a will to Act
What ever I preſcribe.

sp.speaker: Rogaſt.
